text: Tap at Sidebar. Black pour. Coffee, roast, malt, hop and barley aroma. Bitter to the end. Delicious balance of roast and coffee and tree. So good I got another when I didnt need it.
Draft. According to the description it was contracted by lagunitas. It isnt world class but a good lager with a roasty note but light drinkability.

Draught at Lulus, 4/23/17.Dark ebony, undetermined clarity with a light tan head atop showing moderate retention.Roasted barley shows some light bitterness and chocolate in the nose with bits of caramel and vanilla behind it. A bit of leafy, lightly herbal hop notes, perhaps, as well. Pretty light, low aromatics but no alcohol or flaw and nothing aggressive or out-of-style here.Same goes for the mild, very drinkable, gently-hopped flavor. Dry and well-attenuated with a very soft, lightly watery texture showing light chocolate, vegetal and peppery hops adding gentle bitterness and just a touch of cream and light caramel on the finish. Low, fairly engaging carbonation keeps it drinkable and there is no flaw or alcohol.
Some roast and lots of water like you built a dam. Black pour with decent head. Bitter finish. Fairly dry. Tap at Churchkey.

This showed up everywhere in NYC on tax day quite the gimmick they capitalized on but Ill bite. Nice looking dark pour and one finger beige head. Nose is char and some coffee. Tastes of espresso, light cherry, ash, earth and plum. Light bodied and pleasant. 16oz grower from city hops

The Jeffrey, NYC tap: pours dark brown with beige head. Aroma is light chocolate, roast, hints of cafe. Taste is very nutty at the finish. Hints of chocolate, but freshly chewed hazelnut is strong here... not the bullshit flavoring. Nice and complex, but very chuggable.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2017 Draft at Bru Craft. Very dark brown/black pour with soft khaki foam. Top of a keg. Creamier mouthfeel than expected when cold. Lots of dark roasty flavors. Espresso. Semi-sweet cocoa. Burnt toast and burnt toasted nuts. Hints of earth and ash. Amazingly well balanced. Easy finish. Well done.
Not a big fan of black lagers and IPAS but this one was very tasty. One of the better ones.
Very crisp for a dark lager. Very nicely made in the style. Light in a good way, with balance coming from roast malts. Lanesplitter Berkeley.

Draft at Lanesplitter Pizza and Pub, Pours a deep brownish black with a khaki head.
Taste is slightly smokey with hints of black cherry, chocolate, tobacco. Very decent black lager, good stuff.

Keg at Flavor Bistro. Pours deep brown with a frothy, tan head. The nose holds ashy roast, cocoa. Light sweet flavour, with ample charred malts, baking cocoa, strong roast, scorched earth. Medium bodied with average carbonation. Somewhat harsh and bitter on the finish, with more scorched earthy and ashy-woody dryness. Just OK.
From tap at Woods Brewing, Oakland. Black color with beige head. Malty aroma, roasted, coffee, chocolate, caramel. Sweet and bitter, coffee taste. Medium oily body with soft carbonation.

Tap at SF Beer Week Opening Gala.

Pours black, smooth foam.
Aroma is roasted and dark indeed.
Medium body, liquorice, bitter.
Dry, soft, smooth. Good.
On tap at Woods Brewery. Pours black with small beige head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is strong roast, cocoa, cracker, wood. Medium body, roasted malt, chocolate, cracker, dry finish, good.

SAN FRAN: hopwater distribution...pours dark as night in a dimly lit place. Frothy head is caramel in color, stays. Aroma is of Swiss miss combined with light espresso. Enticing you to drink. First sip surprisingly smooth and light, but flavor lingers. Kind of bubbly like a porter, not a smooth stout. A very good creation.

Lagers are not generally my go to. I am obsessed with this beer. Basically the law of diminishing returns, doesnt apply to this beer. Every sip is as fantastic as the first. I get hints of a sweet creamy peanut butter, mixed with chocolate.
Hands down my favorite beer. Dark, rich, and complex yet light and very drinkable.
A good looking brew, dark dark dark with a bubbly beige head. Coffee and nut aroma. Crisp dark roast on the tongue, some oak and brief smoke.
On tap at the Moonlight tasting room in Santa Rosa. Dark pour. Flavor is roasted malts and bread. Finish is slightly bitter.
On tap, Hopmonk Super coffee smell, dark, a bit mysterious...well, maybe not so dramatic. A beer for slow drinking and reflection.

[1/29/16] Draught at Flavor Bistro in Santa Rosa. Black with a tan head. Nice roasty aroma with coffee, nuts. Bitter and slightly sweetish flavor, roasty, with coffee, a bit of chocolate, nuts. Medium-bodied. A good Schwarzbier.
Draft at flavor. Nose full of powdered cocoa. Taste is a bit bitter chocolate with peppery hop character. Interesting.
Great name. Smooth beer. Even if you dont want it youll get it. Dark and smooth it will treat you the way it should
On tap at flavor pours out black topped with a tan head. nose is roast malts coffee sometime chocolate. Taste is more of the roast malts sweetness chocolate and a touch of smoke.

Pours a deep brownish black on tap with fluffy tan head that dissipates slowly to leave moderate lace. Aroma and taste of sweet fruity yeast esters over slight roasty malt notes, pronounced bitterness. Solid for the style, but dont think Id drink more than one.
Draft. Black. Lasting small beige head. Cocoa. Light Smokey. Mild to moderate roast. Mild bitter. Really very nice all around.
Very good lager. My first experience with this beer and second experience with Moonlight. Both beers are exceptional and wish it was available in our home town. Keep up good work Moonlight.

Pours black with a medium tan head...excellent retention and lacing. Aroma has nice roastiness with hints of peat, ash, dark chocolate, molasses and coffee. Flavor follows suit...nice mild spicy hoppiness combined with a delicate complexity of malts. Mouthfeel is medium / full and creamy with a dry roasty finish that has mild bitterness.

In tap at Toronado SF. Black but light is alcohol and taste. At the beginning there are favors of tabacco and coffee. You immediately tell it is lighter and easy to drink for being such a dark beer. Brewed by one guy who is also delivering the beer, great local SF beer. Recommend tasting if given the chance!

Tap at Toronado in a pint glass. Dark black in color. Small tannish head. Aroma is heavy on coffee beans and roasted malts. Taste has plenty of coffee elements and a heavy roast end. Welcomed after a lot of West Coast IPAs. Bright initial taste and an overwhelmingly roasted coffee undertone. Good and worth a sample.

This poured a dark brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of earthy hops, toasty malt, light chocolate. Flavor was similar, nice noble earthy hips, balanced toasted malt, light smoke. Great schwartz.
UPDATED: JUN 29, 2016 Draft. Imagine a packet of cocoa being thrown onto your tongue, and that it quickly dissolves. That, with a bit of coffee thrown in, is this beer.
This is very good. I really liked it. Smooth, light, crisp with a nice roastedness.

"not super impressed with this one. got it by mistake (next to the mirror mirror tap) so the potential for a nice surprise was there, but it was a bit of a bastard. too hoppy and bitter for the style. nothing offensive, and nothing that stood out."

Enjoyed at FWIBF 2014... Dark brown in color... Nutty aroma... Flavor is nutty malts, caramel... Boring brown lager

To me this is my go to beer in the Bay Area.

On tap at Monks Kettle. Black with a foamy tan head. Creamy and roasty aroma. Smooth creamy roasty nutty taste. Silky smooth body. Great!

On tap at Toronado. 
Aroma is all malt. Light roast and chocolate along with some burnt toast and cracker with a hint of caramel. No diacetyl but there are low esters. Low hop aroma as well. No alcohol. 
Appearance is dark brown to black with a thin light tan head that recedes to the edges. 
Flavor is malty sweet with a decent amount of roast an secondary notes of chocolate, burnt toast, a good amount of cracker, and light caramel. Moderate noble hop flavor; some floral spiciness. No diacetyl and a touch of fruity esters, but I could be confusing the eaters with the hops. Hop bitterness is moderate and alcohol notes are not present. 
Mouthfeel is crisp and light as a lager should be. Medium high carbonation. Low astringency in the finish. Low to medium alcohol heat. 
Overall I really like this beer. It's an easy drinking dark lager with more character than the Full Sail Dark Session Lager. The hop flavor is perhaps a bit too pronounced.

On tap @ Copenhagen Beer Festival. Finally a chance not only to taste more American Dark Lager (a rather obscure genre in Europe), but the best of the genre according to Ratebeer. Two good reasons to get my hands on this one. :-) Pours a pitch black body with a huge creamy beige head; a very impressive sight. Aroma is filtered (pot) coffee, dark malts and hints of tar. Taste has more coffee, but this time it reminds me of the powdered/freeze-dried variant instead - like instant Nescafe. There are also hints of leather and milk chocolate in there. It reminds me of a Schwartzbier but is still decidedly different. Smooth, drinkable and well balanced, but not terribly exciting. If this truly is the pinnacle of its genre, Im not gonna be prioritizing more American Dark Lager for a while. Pretty nice beer, though.

@CBF. Pours black with a great creamy longlived tanned head leaving lacing. Aroma is light, hoppy, fruity and malty. Flavor is like aroma. Finishes watery and bitter fruity.
ptich dark, small offwhite head. aroma is roasted malts, smoke. Flavor is roasted notes, smoked and flowery flavor.

Tap @ CBF. Pours black with a brown shine, small brown head. Aroma has black malts, coffee, hoppy citrus, rye bread, caramel a bit of lager yeast. Taste is bready, coffee, rye bread, cold coffee, citric and pineapple hops on the sides of the tongue. Nice balance and a high drinkability.

Draught. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter exstremely roasted flavor. Ashtray notes without tyhat much smoke. Long heavy bitter finish. Creamy palate. Excellent.
Draught. Black coloured. Light brwon head. Roast, sweetness, fruits, caramel and light liqourice. Flavour of rast, caramel, cocoa, liqourice. Meidum bodied. Sweet and roasty end.

On tap at Zeitgeist.  Pours very dark brown, maybe a little red along the edges, with a creamy tan head.  Aromas of roasted coffee and chocolate, as well as some straw and mild pine.  The flavor is roasted cocoa, caramel, toffee, and coffee.  Light and easy-drinking, with porter-like qualities.  Nice for the style.  [701]
Draft at burger. Pours dark brown almost black with tan head. Aroma of malt, taste of malt, nice finish to the caramelly roasted goodness.

Draft at Toronado San Fran. This one pours a dark mahogany color, nearly black and crowned by a small head of khaki colored foam that settles quickly to a thin film. Small spots of lace cling to the glass. The aroma shows roasted coffee, burnt toast, dry cocoa, toasted nuts and a sweet caramel malt base. There is some earthy hop bitterness on the back end as well. The flavor follows suit with the dry, dark cocoa, roasted coffee, toasted nuts, ash, and a hint of licorice. The caramel malt adds a touch of sweetness to balance out the dry, roasted, and burnt flavors. Earthy hops add just the right amount of bitterness on the back end. Medium bodied with ample carbonation that leads to a lengthy, bitter cocoa finish. This is a really nice, easy drinking black lager. Not sure why this is not listed under schwarzbier, but either way this is a good brew.
On tap at Alembic Bar, San Francisco. Black with a tan head. Roasted coffee, light body. Easy drinking, yet strangely complex.

Almost completly black, with a solid moccacoloured head.
Aroma of chocolate malt which totally dominates the nose. 
Flavour is more chocolate malt, nothing bitter just the malt. A hint of wood/oak in it. Medium lenght, medium body and a good carbonation
Summary; An okey beer, which is very one-dimension.

Tap @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Pours deep brown with a lovely, creamy, staying, beige head. Aroma has mild sweetness, light ryr, good cold coffee notes. Medium carbonation, light and rather elegant mouthfeel. Flavour is soft, dry, light grainy, lots of coffee notes. Good dryness. Fairly short finish though. But for the style, it is really lovely.

De barril. Deep dark brown almost black colour. small beige head, ok lacing. Dark malty caramel aroma, Flavour has dark malts and caramel with some coffee and bit chocolate along with a a pleasant bitter hoppiness.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 This has got to be the pinnacle of its style, if not quite the pinnacle of all American brewing.  Ridiculously roasted/charred/blackened.  Coffee.  Dark, dark, dark bitter chocolate.  Hilarious that this made it to Mikkeller bar and Ive never even seen their beer outside of Toronado SF.

Nose is coffee, some barn yard, later weak hops
Feel is thin
Carb is heavy
Taste is burnt malt, coffee, dark chocolate, then bitter hops

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.
Black coloured with a medium sized beige ehad.
Malty and roasted aroma of hay and caramel.
Roasted flavour of caramel, hay and liquorice with notes of hops.
Roasted and hoppy finish.
Draught at MikkellerBAR. Almost black - offwhite head. Burned. Ryebread. Licorice. Coffee. Grassy. Bitter burned. Light bitter hoppy. High malty. Nice.

Toronado. Pours a deep dark brown nearing black with a good white head.  Aroma is toast, nutty slight ash, slight burnt notes, light chocolate, herbal hops.  Flavor is toast, nuts, burnt edges, slight licorice with tobacco leaves, and a mineral clean finish.  Good stuff.  Easy drinking.

12/10/10 (Draft, SF. Now were talking! In short, a tremendous Black Ale, teeming with roasted malt flavors without the weightiness of a richer stout. Nose has roasts, meatiness, almond paste. Flavor has big red berry-infused dark chocolate, ash, mascarpone. Finish dries, but maintains perception of creaminess perhaps due to depth of flavor. Intense, bittersweet, complex.

Tap at Toronado SF at recommendation of the Dogfish Head rep I met that night Bryant! Poured a deep brown to near black with a thick, coffee head that left some pretty serious sheety lace. Aroma is floral, lemon, herbal tea, coffee, hazelnut, bacon, and smoke. Very nice. Taste is pretty heavy on tea tea, newspaper, cardboard, and drying cocoa powder. Palate is dry and papery rather than rich and oily. Thin body is appropriate for style and is not what is detracting from the experience.

Poured like a stout, with a black appearance along with minimal white head that didnt retain well. Smelled of coffee, but was faint. Good smell but could have been stronger I suppose. Taste was very nice, with a crisp coffee/malt taste pervading the palate to go with a watery texture that was actually well done. Drinkable for days, as the tastes were not too strong, and the brew went down almost too easily. Highly recommended if you happen on it.
toast, roasty, black, tan foam, lightly bitter, light body, coffee, chocolate. I love this beer. Death and taxes had become one of my favorite beers.

Black looks with a creamy tan head. Nose was roasted malt, dark chocolate,and coffee. Sweetish flavour with plenty of roast in the house once more, and a slight smokiness. Some hop bitterness kicked in towards the finish. Not my favourite style, but had some good qualities to it.
Tap at Flavor.  Black, brown head, great lacing.  Aroma of dark bitter chocolate and espresso.  Taste is burnt espresso with a smoky edge.  Nice.

On tap at Toronado San Francisco in August 2009.

Pours a shimmering, opaque black. There is a nice tan head and a good deal of lacing. The nose is roasted malt, chocolate, dry coffee, and hints of smoke. The taste brings forward a lot of bitter dark chocolate and some coffee; a bit of sweetness in the finish. Mouthfeel is light and dry. Quite drinkable--as much as I was disappointed by Reality Czech, I was very pleased with this one.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-04-2009

Had this during the Backwoods Brewdown up at Hill Farmstead.  Pours a deep black with a huge creamy tan head.  Cocoa powder, light touch of chococolate.  Cocoa, pepper and light smoke.  Slow pepper, very gentle and subtle.  Slow gentle burn.  Neat.

12 oz pour at City Beer in San Francisco. Pour is a hazed black, with some brown and ruby. A nice tan head tops the beer. Aroma is roasted malt, along with a natural grainy maltiness. Nice blast of pine hops in there aas well. Clean, fresh and crisp. Taste is the nose, roasty malt along with pine hops. As with the nose, crisp clean and fresh. Palate is light bodied, active carbonation and a super clean dry finish. Really drinkable and tasty.

Tap at the BWBD10.  Pours an almost black with a creamy lacing tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and a touch of hops.  Flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, light coffee and a touch of herbal hop notes.

[BBD 10] Dark brown with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of some roast, caramel malts, light cocoa, and wood.  Taste of roast, tobacco, some smoke, caramel malts, some pine, and a dry finish.

Draft at Toad in the Hole. Black with fine lasting tan head and impressive lace; 13 sips from my pint glass are clearly documented! Coffee and grass on the nose. Broad roasty, bitter chocolate, and pungent herbal flavors. Intensity of flavors means a perfectly clean finish is out of the question. Ive been drinking D+T since 12+ years ago, and while its always tasty, there have been times when a yogurty lacto thing has been apparent, and sometimes a more prominent herby flavor crops up.
A decent offering, well worth the money and id possibly get it again. Just didnt knock my socks off. It was ok, kind of bland with a slight chalkiness, dont care much for the style.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2010 My Bottom Line:
Chocolatey malt and a roasted finish are supported by wooden hops and their citrusy edges in this stoutish, well-structured Schwarzbier.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam lingers on the dark brown opacity. 
-One of the two pints I had (at the Hopmonk Tavern, not at Toronado) had a nose which was all iodine. Hard to really get worked up on whats in your glass when the aroma is this problematic. Thankfully, this problem seemed to slowly evaporate with time, and wasnt present at all in the pint I had at Toronado.
-The mouthfeel is crisp even though chocolate malt flavours are salient. 
-Effervescence is loose, increasing drinkability. 
-There is a nice balance between the few sugars and the quiet bitterness.
-The body on this one is richer than any authentic Schwarzbier Ive had.

On tap at Hopmonk Tavern (2.9) and at Toronado (3.7).

23rd April 2010. On tap at the Rake, last of the barrel. Clear brown beer, snall off white head. Sourish wood nose and some cola as well. Palate is smooth and soft but paradoxically gives a crisp carbonated bite. Chocolate and coffee. A bit of sourness and some citrus. Semi dry finish. Love to try this again.

Tap at Toronado.  Deep black pour with a thin tan head.  The nose is a little bit chocolatey and lgihtly roasty as well.  A little bit of chewiness with some sweeter toasted malt on the back of the palate.  Earthy finish but quite clean.  Its a nice, fresh, chewy lager.  A little bit herbal and finishes dryer than I would have expected.
enjoyed on tap at Toronado.  I like the style, and this was a decent example of it.  Served a little cold.  Lacey.  Above average mouthfeel, with chocolate and a little sour.  Good drinkability.

A: The pour is just about black with some nice carbonation and a sturdy khaki colored head.

S: There is not an overwhelming complexity when it comes to the nose, but certainly plenty of intensity. A lot of roast and coffee come through along with even a touch of char.

T: The bitterness of this beer is forcible with a slight acidity. The roast and coffee flavors are also quite pronounced, along with a hint of earthy hops.

M: The body is light-to-medium bud a fairly effervescent feel to the beer makes it a very enjoyable, though it probably heightens the sense of acidity.

D: Its nice to have a good Moonlight beer again after the abomination that is Artemis. Id grab a pint of this again.

Draft at cha cha cha. Pours a black with a light brown head. Aroma is roast chocolate malt hint of hops. Flavor is roast barley with a nice dose of hop and cocoa bitterness in the finish. Damn fine I must say.

Sampled in a 14oz glass at Park Chow in SF. I really liked this brew. Very filling but very crisp in texture and flavor. Drinks smooth. Pours very dark but smooth. Nice coffee/roasted flavoring. Nice brew.

Tap, City Beer Store. This beer pours coffee black with a tight off-white head. The aroma is mild but clean. Theres light coffee, roast, fruit, floral/grassy hops and grain. The beer is smooth and light, quite good for a schwarzbier. The flavor starts mildly sweet and finishes dry. Its a refreshing, drinkable beer.

Pours very dark with a small tan head. Aroma of very dark roasted malt, and coffee. The flavor is burnt and almost skunky with notes of espresso, and licorice. Finishes very bitter and roasted. Everything about this beer is big, except the body and alcohol content. A great mild alternative.

On tap at Toronado 
Appearance: Dark brown with a nice tan head and some lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Dark fruits, caramel 
Taste: Dark malts and fruits, caramel, chocolate 
Very nice beer, light and refreshing.

On tap @Pi Bar during SF Beer week.  This was my first experience with this style, so I dont have a reference point.  Pitch black color belies the french-roasted flavor of the malt.  Suprisingly light finish, but that might be indicative of the style.  Not a firm favorite, but this brew will encourage me to try others from Moonlight.
Had this beer at the opening gala for SF Beer Week.  Pitch black, earthy aroma and flavor with espresso/cocoa notes.  Not heavy and very sessionable.  Get it when you can.
Pours black with a decent tan head and a chocolate aroma. There is a hearty roasted malt flavor with a hint of chocolate. Neither too sweet nor too bitter. Very tasty.
Keg at the Rake. Almost black with a tan head. Mild roastiness with very few hops. Smooth carbonation. An unremarkable dark lager.

Tap in The Rake. Alround rating: Very burnt black malt, seriously roasty, a bit of sweetness, grassy hop, the carbonation is very fine. Im guessing if your into roastyness this would be awsome. Im not but its still an alright drink due to the carbonation.

On tap @ Toronado.  Pours a deep black color with a small off-white  head.  Smoky, earthy aroma, roasted malts.  Again, lots of roasted malt in the body, licorice, with a sweet tanginess.  I like the style, love this beer.
Pretty sure I had this at the Toronado.  Remember it being darkly colored in a good looking way, smooth, lightly roasted and bodied, and easy to drink.  Decent.

(Draught)  Pours a dark brown body with a small beige head.  Aroma of roasted grain, grass, cocoa, nuts, caramel, and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, and hops (grass, earth) with a creamy mouthfeel.

From tap at Flavour. Pours dark brown with a small deep amber glare and a slowly collapsing tan head. Aroma is light butterish and roasted. Bitter and roasted malt flavoured with a light butterish note coming through. Ends slight butterish.
Drank it on tap at San Franciscos Toronado thanks to a friend we met from Nicaragua.  Pitch black color, seems heavy, however it is light bodied, smooth and creamy, roasted flavor.

Draft. A pitch black beer with a brown head. The aroma has notes of butter and roasted malt. The flavor is sweet and buttery with notes of roasted malt and chocolate, leading to a roasted finish. More like a mild than a Schwartzbier.

Shaker pour at Tornado. Color is black as heck.  Aroma is very roasted with light hops peaking through out of a very clean profile. Flavor is the same, very easy to drink with lots of character but not sweet.  Not much more to say, its just good.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: 6/18/09 on draft at the nhc. Aroma is super chocolaty with a nutty, woody note. Appears is nearly black with a cream/tan head that is well maintained. Flavor is very rich, sweet and toasty with a clean finish. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with slight creaminess. Overall, traditional yet sweet and not worse for it.

On tap at Toronado in San Francisco. Pours a black body with a frothy, inch thick, khaki tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves some nice lacing. Aroma is very fat butterscotch chocolate malts, smoke, and roasted coffee. The roasted nose isnt as intense as a typical stout, but for a schwarzbier, this is rather pleasant. Some hints of fruitcake as well. Flavor is similar. Light bodied and smooth, but more of the big body taste before a crisp and dry finish. Fat chocolates and butter with a good amount of earth and roasted coffees to finish this out and linger for quite awhile. Overall, a pretty cool beer. Lots of dark flavors in a lager make me quite happy.

On tap at Toronado SD.  Dark hazy drown pour, nice frothy tan head.  Lots of roasted malt, smoke, earthy peet flavor, chocolate, and hints of fruit and cold coffee.  An excelent lager.  The body was light and clean.  Easy to drink.

Tap at Toranado: Near opaque pour with a khaki head. Tons of black malt roast in the nose with some coffee character. Typical clean schwarzbier. Velvety and grainy flavor. Heavy roast with some charred notes of tobacco and black malt. Remains fluffy and clean. Some coffee roast as well. A solid interpretation of a Schwarbier.

On tap at Toronado, San Francisco, with Phyllis, 24th Mar 09. Pitch black, quite still. A flavoursome dark lager. Great roasted flavour that really sticks around for you to savour. Slightly fruity nose. A great dark lager.

WOW what a surprise. I had this on draft @ the Toronado while in SF. great chocolate flavor and thought this was either a really light stout or a porter I was puzzled trying to figure out what it was. What an easy to drink beer. At 4% man I could slam this one for quite a few pints.Such a great tasting easy to drink beer. Wish this one was available locally but as of now all I can do is tell my friends to try this while on vacation in Cali..Hats off on a great brew HIGHLY recommend!

My first beer on tap at the infamous Toronado in SF. Black as sin pour with a moderate tan head and no lacing. Surprisingly stout like flavor of chocolate and coffee with an excellent smoky flavor to boot. Smooth and dry, an excellent example of the style and a steal at 3 bucks a pint!

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2010 Always on tap at Toronado in SF.  Very nice example of the schwarzbier style. Black appearance with a nice tan head. Coffee and roasted malt on the aroma.  Has the kind of chocolate and coffee flavors you expect from a stout, with roasted malts, but much lighter on the body so you know its a lager.

On tap at Flavor in Santa Rosa.

This was a pretty tasty beer, it was almost like the dry roastiness of a porter meets Belgian candy sweetness. Liked it.
Tap at the Stumptown Brewpub. Aroma is mostly chocolate. Black color with a good tan head. Chocolate and dark malt flavors. A bit toasty. Quite smooth. Extremely drinkable.

Draft @ Piaci Pub & Pizza, Fort Bragg, CA. Pours a black color with a small longlasting off-white head. Has a roasted malty aroma with hints of chocolate and licorice. Roasted malty bitter chocolate and hoppy flavor with some hints of licorice. Has a roasted malty hoppy finish ith some hints of smoke in the aftertaste. A nice schwarzbier.

Tap at Hopmonk Tavern. The body was black with red hints at the edges. A tan orange colored head was on top. The aroma was licorice with some dark bread hints. There was some milk chocolate. The taste was lightly roasted with cocoa and cola. There was also a little bit of milk chocolate.

On tap at Obriens.  I thought that I would like this one more than I did, although it was definitely quality.  Dark brown to black in color with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, cocoa, and chocolate.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa, earth with strong hints of chalk.  Pretty good stuff here.
UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 This is a great session beer.  Nice dark roasted flavors with a nice light body.  Very drinkable.
Dark brown, long lasting roasted malts, roasted coffee, roasted dark chocolate, dry.

Draft @ Toronado.  Pours a dark, chocolate-brown color; medium-brown head with decent retention and patchy, fine-bubbled lacing.  Generous aroma of nougat, lightly roasted malts, and toasted marshmallow; nicely dry, chocolatey.  Medium mouthfeel: chewy nougat and dark malts, plenty of chocolate, along with some toasted marshmallow / caramel / sweetness, following the nose; nicely toasty mid-palate and in the finish: lots of chewy chocolate and nougat; dry.

On tap @ Lanesplitter in Berkeley poured a translucent dark brown nearly black with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee anbd bakers cocoa. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors ofcoffe, bakers cocoa and roasted malt with a smooth lingering roasty bitter finish.

Tap @ Hamilton’s.  Black body, minimal ring of white foam crowning glass. Smells of espresso beans and coffee. Taste is more bitter than sweet with a comfortable hop force. Coffee, roasted dark and lovely, gently wrapped in mocha.

porter, porter, porter - but brewed as a lager. 
This is an interesting little beer. lot’s of roast, lot’s of dark fruit and a nice hop flavour in the finish. not like any schwarzbier i have tried before but dam good. 
Toronado...
Tap at Toronado. Pretty damn good for a lager. Thought it was a stout at first. Very easy drinking, very tasty.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Draught at The Red, Santa Cruz.   Pours a dark coffee black with a big pillowy brown head that has excellent retention.   Roasty and slightly sweet aroma with dark chocolate dust evident.  Pretty roasty and dry, but still retains enough malt sweetness to smooth out the black malt.   Just enough bitterness, but stays smooth and clean.   Light to medium bodied with an almost creamy feel.   I’m floored by the richness and balance of the flavors in this one, and I had no idea that it was only 4.2%.   This would make and excellent session beer; the roasty chocolate flavors are so well balanced that you just want more and more.

On tap @ Toronado SF.  Black color with a sparse thin tan head.  Pumpernickel and light roast aroma, slight lactose.  Nice even mild roast on the taste, finishes which a little residual roast and not much bitterness. A well executed schwarz.

On Tap at Barley and Hops Tavern. Pours a faintly translucent black with a small tan head. Coffee and bread dominate the head, and lager crispness, faint vanilla, and non-overpowering espresso dominate the flavor. Schwarzbier with a bit more complexity; unique and lovely.

On Tap. Drank along side the new Stone 12. Pours with a black body covered by a small, light brown head. Great Lcing. Coffee grounds and a bit of fruit in the aroma. A lot of coffee grounds in the taste along with a burnt maltiness. A pretty nice, light body, but a bit on the fizzy side of things.

On tap at Toronado. Death and taxes are certain, the fact this a schwarzbier? Not so much -- The murk and the chewiness are more like a porter. Pours opaque blackish brown with a dense and lacy beige head. Medium body, minimal carbonation. Brown sugar, chocolate and pine in the nose and taste, dry pine finish.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 On draft, pours almost opaque black with a ruddy aura, with a whipping cream mocha head.   D&T has a robust character and thick palate yet is light-bodied and moderate in alcohol.
A moderate vienna roast coffee aroma persists in flavor-- with mild licorice, bittersweet cocoa and pistachio notes. 
Moderate effervescence and good lacing, and a low acid hop pull hovers in the long dry-malt finish.

Poured on tap at Lanesplitter pub an inky black with thin tan head and little carbonation.  Aroma is roasty with grains and toffee.  Flavor is a bit nutty, roast coffee, toffee, some slight graininess and a touch of smokey carcoal.  The after taste is quite hoppy but doesnt come out in the body. Palate is stick chewy an a touch sweet at first and then lightens up in the middle and end with strong flavor and touch of bitter.  Wow, liked this one it brings lots of strong flavor yet easy drinking.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2008 On tap at Flavor in Santa Rosa. Dark red-brown-black color with a fine, creamy, tan mocha head.  Quite sweet caramel and toffee aromas with a coffee edge and some light fermentation notes.  Flavor posesses lots of dark roasted grain bitterness with intense smokiness.  The body is disarmingly light which really puts the intense flavors front and center.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 Tap @ Hamiltons in SD. Totally opaque black with scattered lacing. Slight diacetyl and oil in nose. Excellent roasted malt flavors, some pleasant huskiness, excellent and one of the best schwartzbiers Ive had outside Europe.

On tap at The Trappist in Oakland, CA. Dark, dark black with thick, pillowy head. Rich, very strong aroma of fresh roasted cofee beans, more moderate air of dark chocolate, along with some earthiness and rich malty nuances as well. Flavor is VERY dry; tons of roasted malt and with substantial hoppiness. Ashen, smoky finish. Dry and roasty to the extreme. Not my thing, but could be just it for someone. I dig the aroma, but it could do with some more balancing sweetness.

How appropriately, rated the week of April 15th. Did the taxes, feel like death.... Pours almost black with nice off white head. Nose and flavor are the same, with malt and a light smokiness. Mouthfeel is somewhat creamy with a clean, dry finish.

Draught. Smooth, easy drinking. Aroma not parrticularly distinct-slight fruitiness. Flavor quite complex, with a combo of malt, light acidity, bubbly spiciness, cloves, slight fennel tones, and a touch of bubblegum, plus very subtle roasted grain.  Alcohol is light, but I wasnt in the mood for getting sloshed! Great California interpretation of the style.
On tap at Liars Club.  Surprisingly great.  Black with almost no head.  Chocolate and grain aroma.  Roasty burnt taste with a smokey finish.

On draft at OBriens (months ago).  Almost fully black and opaque, with many bubbles clinging to the lower sides of the glass - reminiscent of a coke or rootbeer.  Both aroma and flavor are roasty and herby, blackened malts, dandelion milk, hints of soy sauce and slight bitter chocolate finish.  Kind of stoutlike with more crispness and carbonation.  Light to medium body and tingly carbonation in the mouthfeel.

Draft at Toronado. Blackish body, tan head that lasts fairly well. Aroma is very roasted with lesser chocolate and coffee notes, some caramel. Moderate hopping here, which is basically high for the style. Very drinkable, big flavors for such a low ABV. Good Schwarz.

Tap @ Tornado 1/4/08, recommedation from Bikesandbeers brother Marty.  Porus black with a thin tan head.  No noticeable armoa.  Taste is sweet, mellow and malty, very drinkable, smoky and roasty and yummy.

Ive had Death and Taxes many times over the years, having grown up in the Sonoma County region, and had it again for the first time in a while last night. The nose is sweet, caramel, roasty. The head is thick and tan and laces well throughout the pint. The flavor is slightly bitter java, cocoa beans, and a little burnt caramel. You can really get the flavor of the chocolate malts. Mouthfeel is nice, and beer is deceiving light as a black lager style. Overall, a really solid standby, though the pubs apparently dirty lines lent a little residual sourness this time around.

On tap at The Red in Santa Cruz. 
Black with tan head, opaque. Good retention and lacing. 

Smell is very appealing; roasted malt brings cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee bean aromas. 

Absolutely delicious, this beer tastes like a chocolate covered coffee bean. Hints of vanilla, slight hop bitterness, smoke. Excellent balance, flavors meld very seamlessly. 

Perfect carbonation, full body, low alcohol all contribute to a superb mouthfeel. 

Forget all day, I could drink this all week!
Draft at Kern River Brewpub; Nose of caramel, molasses, and coffee; clear dark brown with a big, glass-lacing beige head; flavor of light  hop bitterness, grain, caramel, and a light coffee note.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2008 Ive had this on tap several times at Flavor and Black Rose, both in Santa Rosa, over the past 5 years or so.  Having had it again today, I can say that this is a nice fairly rich, but still light bodied beer resembling a more full-bodied, tastier dry stout.  It is black with a big, dense, brown head that lasts and leaves excellent, rich, even rings of lacing.  The aroma is rich, dark toasted malt, nuts, molasses, caramel, and a hint of chocolate.  The taste is similar, but without the caramel and with a strongly toasted malt emphasis, hints of chocolate and coffee, burnt toast, with initial sweetness balanced by a zesty, spciy bitterness.  It has a long, mellow finish and is satisfying, smooth and fairly light while having fairly full body and flavor.  It is not especially complex, though, and is ultimately fairly straightforward.

Tap. Aroma starts with heavy malt notes of molasses, burnt, strong coffee and dark bread, light hop smell of herbs and light yeast of leather, with soy sauce and cola in the background. Head is a creamy/bubbly off-white and has excellent thick lacing and is mostly lasting. Flavor starts lightly sweet and acidic and finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is watery, light to medium and has a lively carbonation. The depth of the aroma sets this beer above similar styles.

On tap at the Magnolia Pub. Pours jet black with thin mocha head. The aroma is big with toffee, burnt malts and dark roasted coffee beans. The taste is inviting rich malt complexity. A solid burnt charred maltiness hits first with lighter roasted malts, dark roasted coffee beans, a hint of toffee and some licorice. At the finish a mild astringency enters to linger with the burnt malts and coffee notes. It smells more like toffee than it tastes.

On tap at the Beachwood BBQ.  Pours a dark black color with brown sugar edges and a firm head of tan foam.  Loads of chocolate saturates the aroma, along with dark caramel toffee, medium roast coffee, and even a hint of prune skin fruitiness.  Light bodied, fizzy carbonated mouthfeel.  Starts out somewhat sweet with flavors of chocolate and nutty molasses.  This dries up mid-palate with some roast coffee bitterness.  An almost undetectable trace of butterscotch suggests diacetyl, but is very minor if there.  Lots of herbal, minty hops round out the finish nicely.  Impressive malt flavors and complexity for the low ABV and hopped generously, yet appropriately.

On tap at Toronado in San Francisco. Deep walnut brown, almost black, with a thin brown pad of a head. Chocolate aroma with an interesting smoked-cork aroma too. Again chocolatey, with figgy/fruity elements and a well-hopped bitter finish. Only faintly smokey. Medium mouthfeel. More porter-ish in my mind, but awesome nonetheless.

text:
Draught, Toronado.

Body is dark brown.

Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (roasted grain, coffee, caramel, nuts).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Delightful...a very tasty malt-bomb.

Many times.  From tap at Lanesplitter in Oakland, Berkeley and at Vapariso.. Varies sometimes, but pretty consistent. Coffee, roasty, smoky aroma and flavors.  A good hop punch too.  Great flavor from what appears to be Nugget hops?  Drinks so much like a quaffable ale I sometimes forget this is a lager.  Very enjoyable, and my personal favorite of all dark beers in this alcohol range.  A great beer.  Thanks Brian!
Weak aroma in the beginning continued by a welcoming nice cereal taste. It just looks wonderful, so dark in the pint glass. unexpectedly wonderful to accompain with mac and cheese and bbq ribs.

Had on tap at Toronado in SF. VERY dark beer. Would have sworn by the look that it was a stout. Poured dark brown no head. Taste was light sweet milk, malts, and molases. Slightly bitter finish. Very good beer.

Draught at The Toranado, SF, CA. Beer is opaque, dark brown with a tiny, frothy, white, mostly and quickly diminishing head.

The aroma is malty with moderate-to-heavy notes of lacto-creamy milk chocoate, moderate notes of coffee, caramel, roasted grain, lighter notes of toasted nuts, blackstrap molases; Hoppy with light notes of herbal resin/pine; Yeasty with a trace of dough; Miscellaneous trace notes of tart berry and dried black fruits.

The favor is moderately sweet, moderately-to-heavily bitter, lightly acidic with a long, warm, moderate-to-heavily bitter, lightly sweet, grippy finish. Roasty on the rets.

The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

On tap at the 21st Amendment brewpub as a guest beer. Seems that 21st is carrying a lot more guest beers these days due to the overextended demands of canning their own beer and trying to serve tap beer to a thirsty public at the pub. This beer pours dark brown with a big beige head. The finish is  tart sourness. Has a strong chocolate aroma. Great lacing left behind in the glass. The finish is very drying and chalky. Again, a WAY overrated beer by some.
Draft.  Pitch black in color with a frothy, tan head.  Rich roastedvmalt aroma with yeastiness.  Strong smoked flavor with a slight fruitiness.  Clean, dry finish with a residual smokiness.

LOL - Nice when my notes say Death in Texas - hehehe. Nice black color, tan head. Nice roasted malt nose - medium long lasting. I would say this is not a Schwarzbier. It is a unique creation - and that is truly tasteable.
24 april 07 on tap.  very dark!  aroma of smoke,  licorice.  Flavors of salami, smoke.  very dark roasted malt flavor.  awesome texture.  full bodied.  rich long lasting smoke finish.

On tap @ the Linkery.   Dark color, aroma of coffee and roasted malts.   Flavor is strong on the coffee with a sour, almost bitter finish.  A little watery - almost like a foreign stout.  Pretty good as a session beer, but nothing about this beer grabs my attention.

(On tap - Toronado) Completely opaque black with a dense and creamy, beige head leaving laces. Lightly burned, licorice-like aroma. Medium body with roasted - lightly burned - malt, again with some licorice. Very bitter finish. Excellent. 250307

Had on tap at Hydro in Calistoga. Very dark colored, very light-bodied, VERY FLAVORFUL. Most schwarzs Ive had previously fell short in the flavor category, but not this one. It had as much flavor as a dark and robust porter. Actually, thats exactly what it tasted like. Plenty of roasted/burnt malt flavors and aromas dominate the profile of this bad boy. Nice.
Pours with a dark brown body topped by a thin head and little lacing.  Its bitter and roasty with a slight malt character and a little sourness.  Light to medium bodied and a touch dry.
Tap @ OBriens. Very dark upon pouring. Very sweet roasty aroma with alot of chocolate. Roasted coffee and sweet chocolate dominate flavors. Very full for the low abv.
Draught. Opaque black with tan head. No lace. Roasty aroma accented by chocolate and caramel. Coffee and chocolate are rounded out nicely by a touch of sweetness.
Very nice beer provided by my nemesis The Fly. Roasty coffee aroma that carried through into the flavor without overpowering it.

Thanks to Alan (fly) for sharing this beer. From a growler poured at the brewery. Pours black with a tan head and good lacing. Huge coffee and light chocolate in the nose. Coffee, chocolate, and lactose in the flavor but with a smooth dry finish. Very drinkable and well made beer.
Draft. Blackish beer with a thin tan head. Low roasty aroma. Roasty flavor with caramel backing and balanced hop bitterness. Roastiness not overpowering.
Tap @ Barclays. Malty, chocolatey aroma and flavor. Slightly sweet. Thin, watery palate but full if flavor.

Dark brown colour.  Fairly rich malty, chocolatey aroma.  Full malt character is sweet and rounded with light roasty accents.  Has a bit of chewiness and, surprisingly, late alcohol.  Drinks fairly big.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2006 Draught at Toronado, San Francisco.  Opaque black, no head. Sweetish and very roasty with clean rounded mouthfeel. Dominated by hop flavours - grapefruit and licorice. The malt character is its weak side - its very clean and straightforward, leaving it far behind the top examples of the style.

Dark brown with a moka head. Light chocolate malt aroma. Rather restrained chocomalt with crisp german hops, light fruity esters. Decent schwarze, very simple. Russian River Beer Revival & Barbecue Cook-Off, August 20, 2005.

On tap, Zeitgeist. Black, but light body, small white head.  Light mouthfeel.  Huge roasted coffee aroma.  Really balanced roast taste all over a lager body.  Wow, this is just about the best example of this style I have ever had.  Excellent.

(draft, Toronado) Black body with tan head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, coffee, lactose, light cocoa, some grapefruit underneath.  Creamy medium body.

(Draft: Liars Club in San Diego, CA) In a word, roasty!  The nose is strongly roasty, with some chocolate and coffee, and minimally sweet.  And accordingly, the flavor is also strongly roasty with lots of cofee.  Its smoky, chocolaty, and has some corn/grain flavor, but its minimally sweet.  The roast and hops lend a moderate bitterness.  Medium bodied and dry on the palate.  The beer pours such a dark brown, its as close to being black as you can get without being black.  The tan head rises to half an inch in height after the pour, and settles to a thin film, but succeeds in leaving a dense curtain of lace on the glass.  Very nice beer.  Hopefully Ill see more beers from Moonlight down here in San Diego.

Dark. roasty, but as the brewer demands, not a schwartzbier. Nor porter nor stout. A unique creation that manages to blend well the dark tones with some sharp hop bitterness. The only thing reminiscent of a schwartz is the color and something of a watery texture. Realy enjoyed as I did all their other beers and will look forward trying again.
Very dark, with chocolate and herb taste. Strong smoky taste. A little on the bitter side, but very flavorful.
Opaque black colour with thin tan head. Medium roasted malt nose. Distinct roasted malt taste with dry roasted malt finish.
An oily pour with just a mark of head. Rich, dark chocolate and burnt hazelnuts, espresso and no bullshit. This is a well crafted lager.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2009    Huge complex LAGER, that has changed many minds about lagers. Burnt cocoa and rich honey and molasses notes. Lite smoke at first that leaves very quickly.  Mocha and lite hop finish clean and relatively dry. great beer.

Pitch black coloured body with absolutely no head. Aroma of burnt malt, some caramel and a bit of overroasted coffee. Not the best aroma around, thats for sure. Medium-bodied; Burnt malt flavour with a smoky nuance behind. Aftertaste bittered by all the flavours-no sweetness at all! Overall, great to try, but lacking in so many dimensions! I sampled this pint from draught at Toronado in San Francisco, California on the second day of 10-June-2004...our first was spent in Sydney, Australia.
Tap.  Opaque, medium-tan head.  Licoriche-chocolate smell; typical schwarzbier.  Full-bodied and rather nice.  Raisin, prominent malts.  Good stuff.
on tap at toronado. cocoa powder aroma, quite smooth and grainy if a little dull in the finish

Black body, minimal ring of white foam crowning glass. Smells of espresso beans and coffee. Taste is more bitter than sweet with a comfortable hop force. Coffee, roasted dark and lovely, gently wrapped in mocha. Aftertaste is drying and bitter hops, almost IPAish. Sampled on draught at Toronado in San Francisco, CA.

On draught at Toronado.  05.22.04  Pours black and thick looking.  Smells like a smoked out campfire in the morning over burnt coffee.  All charred malts and minimal head.  Chewy but thin texture.  I didnt realize this was a schwarz until just now and my impression makes much more sense.  Probably my favorite of the style so far.
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2004 Tap, Toronado, San Francisco. A pretty unique dark lager. Mashy/oaty, quite ashy and salty, pretty big hit of hops and bitterness. Pretty tasty, but a little unbalanced.

(tap @ hoptown pleasanton). i think the waitress may have used our sample as her ashtray because that's what it tasted like. this is one beer that i had no desire to drink after a sip or two. really shitty.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2007 Sewer aroma with burnt onion.  Tastes like cigarettes.  I think i gotta rerate this one.

REERATE!!!:

dark brown. vanilla cappuccino aroma. flavor is vanilla & toast. burnt wet cigs-> AGAIN!
UPDATED: MAR 28, 2004 on tap at the Kezar near haight.  black color with a thin tan head, medium stay.  high hop bitter, burnt/toasted malt. no aroma, med carbonation.
On tap @ Cato's.  Black body with brown head.  Sweet chocolate aroma.  Malty chocolate coffee flavor.  Carbonation is very flat.  Found this beer to be much mellower than others have.

Dark black color, with a dark purple tint that rather pretty. Medium head. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee. A medium bodied Schwarthbeir. Malts are roasted, coffee and chocolate. Hops are slightly bitter. Very smooth. Lots of flavor. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Tap: Black appearance with a light brown head.  Great coffee and roasted malts taste.  Very crisp beer with tons of flavor.
Gah!  Too much coffee flavor.  This is a lager?  Who knew?  It grew on me, but I'm not as nuts about it as other folks seem to be...
Black with light brown thick head. Roasted nose. Full bodied roasted espresso flavor.Great lace

Tap @ Toronado in San Francisco.  Solid black with a laced light-brown head which was highly diminished.  A sweet roasted malt aroma and flavor.  Coffee flavors pour through the aftertaste.  A real treat.
Deep dark color and dark flavors like espresso and cocoa.  Perfect sweetness and strength.  Delightful.

Choco-coffee nose.  Roasted and woody overtones. This is complex and weird at the same time. Gets points for trying something different and for the most part succeeding.  Chewy, experimental, and good.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 This is a richly complex beer, tried on a lark on tap at Amnesia SF. The aroma hit and immediately rang 9-plus. Tobacco, roasty malts, burnt paper, like a pencil burning in a speeding pencil sharpener. The color is black as pitch. Dry light body with Moms Folgers coffee flavors, minerals, and well integrated bitter. A very smooth, easy roast (near smoke) finish.  Would be excellent late night with a cigar. This is a great beer!
This was one yummy beer. I had no idea it was a lager until after I had finsished the beer. Tasted more like a silky smooth porter with a very nice roasted taste.

Woah, this one was a surprize!  The only American-brewed schwartzbier that Im aware of, this beer has a fantastically roasty flavor that would be the envy of any porter or stout.  Very smooth, since it is a lager, but waves of malt and hop complexity make it one of the most exciting pints Ive had in a while.  Magnificent.
